item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Aeschylus
item.description: "I know how men in exile feed on dreams" -- Aeschylus

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Edgar Allan Poe
item.description: "I felt that I breathed an atmosphere of sorrow." -- Edgar Allan Poe

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Dante Alighieri
item.description: "The experience of this sweet life." -- Dante Alighieri

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Thomas Mann
item.description: "He who loves the more is the inferior and must suffer." -- Thomas Mann

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.description: "He knew that when he kissed this girl, and forever wed his unutterable visions to her perishable breath, his mind would never romp again like the mind of God." -- F. Scott Fitzgerald

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Al Capp
item.description: "Abstract art is a product of the untalented, sold by the unprincipled to the utterly bewildered." -- Al Capp

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ernest Hemingway
item.description: "It's none of their business that you have to learn how to write. Let them think you were born that way." -- Ernest Hemingway

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Gustave Flaubert
item.description: "What better occupation, really, than to spend the evening at the fireside with a book, with the wind beating on the windows and the lamp burning bright...Haven't you ever happened to come across in a book some vague notion that you've had, some obscure idea that returns from afar and that seems to express completely your most subtle feelings?" -- Gustave Flaubert

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "Yes: I am a dreamer. For a dreamer is one who can only find his way by moonlight, and his punishment is that he sees the dawn before the rest of the world." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Abraham Lincoln
item.description: "I will prepare and some day my chance will come." -- Abraham Lincoln

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Leo Tolstoy
item.description: "In that brief glance Vronsky had time to notice the restrained animation that played over her face and fluttered between her shining eyes and the barely noticeable smile that curved her red lips. It was as if a surplus of something so overflowed her being that it expressed itself beyond her will, now in the brightness of her glance, now in her smile." -- Leo Tolstoy

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Milan Kundera
item.description: "The heaviest of burdens crushes us, we sink beneath it, it pins us to the ground. But in love poetry of every age, the woman longs to be weighed down by the man's body.The heaviest of burdens is therefore simultaneously an image of life's most intense fulfillment. The heavier the burden, the closer our lives come to the earth, the more real and truthful they become. Conversely, the absolute absence of burden causes man to be lighter than air, to soar into heights, take leave of the earth and his earthly being, and become only half real, his movements as free as they are insignificant. What then shall we choose? Weight or lightness?" -- Milan Kundera

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ernest Hemingway
item.description: "Poor Faulkner. Does he really think big emotions come from big words? He thinks I donâ€™t know the ten-dollar words. I know them all right. But there are older and simpler and better words, and those are the ones I use." -- Ernest Hemingway

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "Is it advisable to spread out all the conveniences of culture before people to whom a few steps up a stair to a library is a sufficient deterrent from reading?" -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "Wealth is the product of man's capacity to think." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ernest Hemingway
item.description: "A cat has absolute emotional honesty: human beings, for one reason or another, may hide their feelings, but a cat does not." -- Ernest Hemingway

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Jean Rhys
item.description: "....one of those long, romantic novels, six hundred and fifty pages of small print, translated from French or German or Hungarian or something -- because few of the English ones have the exact feeling I mean. And you read one page of it or even one phrase of it, and then you gobble up all the rest and go about in a dream for weeks afterwards, for months afterwards -- perhaps all your life, who knows? -- surrounded by those six hundred and fifty pages, the houses, the streets, the snow, the river, the roses, the girls, the sun, the ladies' dresses and the gentlemen's voices, the old, wicked, hard-hearted women and the old, sad women, the waltz music -- everything. What is not there you put in afterwards, for it is alive, this book, and it grows in your head. 'The house I was living in when I read that book,' you think, or 'This colour reminds me of that book." -- Jean Rhys

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "The truth is not for all men but only for those who seek it." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "She thought: at this moment, the glass stem between his fingers feels just like the one between mine. We have this much in common." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "The world is perishing from an orgy of self-sacrificing." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "Discussion in class, which means letting twenty young blockheads and two cocky neurotics discuss something that neither their teacher nor they know." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Lemony Snicket
item.description: "Wicked people never have time for reading. It's one of the reasons for their wickedness." -- Lemony Snicket

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "Have you felt it too? Have you seen how your best friends love everything about you- except the things that count? And your most important is nothing to them; nothing, not even a sound they can recognize." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "I would give the greatest sunset in the world for one sight of New York's skyline. Particularly when one can't see the details. Just the shapes. The shapes and the thought that made them. The sky over New York and the will of man made visible. What other religion do we need? And then people tell me about pilgrimages to some dank pesthole in a jungle where they go to do homage to a crumbling temple, to a leering stone monster with a pot belly, created by some leprous savage. Is it beauty and genius they want to see? Do they seek a sense of the sublime? Let them come to New York, stand on the shore of the Hudson, look and kneel. When I see the city from my window - no, I don't feel how small I am - but I feel that if a war came to threaten this, I would throw myself into space, over the city, and protect these buildings with my body." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "Every form of happiness is private. Our greatest moments are personal, self-motivated, not to be touched. The things which are sacred or precious to us are the things we withdraw from promiscuous sharing. But now we are taught to throw everything within us into public light and common pawing. To seek joy in meeting halls. We haven't even got a word for the quality I mean--for the self-sufficiency of man's spirit. It's difficult to call it selfishness or egotism, the words have been perverted, they've come to mean Peter Keating. Gail, I think the only cardinal evil on earth is that of placing your prime concern within other men. I've always demanded a certain quality in the people I liked. I've always recognized it at once--and it's the only quality I respect in men. I chose my friends by that. Now I know what it is. A self-sufficient ego. Nothing else matters." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by George Orwell
item.description: "What can you do, thought Winston, against the lunatic who is more intelligent than yourself, who gives your arguments a fair hearing and then simply persists in his lunacy?" -- George Orwell

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by George Orwell
item.description: "He was an embittered atheist (the sort of atheist who does not so much disbelieve in God as personally dislike Him), and took a sort of pleasure in thinking that human affairs would never improve." -- George Orwell

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by George Orwell
item.description: "Being in a minority, even in a minority of one, did not make you mad. There was truth and there was untruth, and if you clung to the truth even against the whole world, you were not mad." -- George Orwell

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "The question isn't who is going to let me; it's who is going to stop me." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Bridgett add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "The hardest thing to explain is the glaringly evident which everybody has decided not to see." -- Ayn Rand
